awd_titl_txt: Ecological and evolutionary constraints on the design of synthetic microbiomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Human bodies, food systems, and natural ecosystems are all dependent on the activities of microbial communities, commonly known as microbiomes. Microbiologists have identified the diversity of parts (microbial species) within many microbiomes, but they have a very limited understanding of how these parts fit together and how they change over time. Without a set of general assembly instructions for microbiomes, it is difficult to predictably manipulate these systems. This research will use microbes isolated from three fermented foods - fermented tea, sourdough, and cheese - to identify how communities of microbes evolve and the implications of this evolution for manipulating and designing microbial ecosystems. These food microbiomes are relatively simple systems (~2-10 species per microbiome) that have been cultivated for many years in different environments around the world. By identifying how evolution impacts the assembly of these model systems, this research will begin to provide microbiome assembly instructions that can be used in medicine, agriculture, and industry. The popularity of these model systems will be leveraged to improve public understanding of science and increase participation in microbiome research. Through the development of the Citizen Synthetic Ecology Network (CSEN), hundreds of volunteers will submit fermented food microbiomes that will be used in the proposed research. An Evolution in Your Kitchen education module will allow high school students to evolve fermented food microbiomes. The PI's online microbial outreach platform, MicrobialFoods.org, will disseminate infographics on basic concepts in microbiome science, synthetic ecology, and systems biology.  
 
High-throughput sequencing surveys have rapidly unveiled patterns of microbial diversity, but the mechanisms that control the assembly of microbiomes have not been identified. Using a synthetic ecology framework, this project will determine the causes and consequences of the evolution of core microbiome components for the assembly of synthetic communities. The research will determine how core microbiome species have diversified functions across microbial communities and how this functional divergence leads to variable microbial interaction networks and microbiome assembly processes. The genomic and functional diversity of core microbiome species from globally distributed fermented food microbiomes will be characterized through genome sequencing and in vitro community assays. Experimental evolution will be used to determine the mechanisms that drive diversification of core microbiome components. Impacts of the diversification will be measured by assessing interchangeability, invasibility, and stability of synthetic communities.

por.por_cntn:
Microbiomes play critical roles in global ecosystem processes, human health, and the productivity of food systems. As scientists have sifted through the microbiomes across all corners of our planet, they have often discovered many strains of the same microbial species living together in microbial communities. These strains are closely related versions of the same species, but have genetic differences that make each strain behave slightly differently. This strain diversity is widely acknowledged, but the roles that these strains play in the formation of microbial communities has been largely unknown. Are strains just ?genetic noise? in the complex diversity of microbial communities? Or do different types of strains play unique roles in microbiomes?

This project used three widespread and easily manipulated systems - cheese rinds, sourdough starters, and kombucha tea - to understand how strain diversity impacts the ecology of microbiomes. We used collections of strains of common species found in each of these systems to recreate experimental microbiomes in the laboratory. We discovered that altering the strains in a community can dramatically impact many important ecological processes, including the rate of microbial community development, responses to invading microbes, stress tolerance, and the ability of the microbiome to create desired industrial outcomes. These findings illustrate the importance of considering strain diversity when engineering or managing microbiomes.

As we developed and used the food model systems, we also had opportunities to better characterize the biodiversity of these culturally and economically significant food microbiomes. We worked with hundreds of food producers and home fermenters around the world to collect samples of cheese rinds, sourdough, and kombucha. Using metagenomic and genomic approaches, we collected some of the most comprehensive data on the biodiversity of these fermentations. In cheese rinds, we revealed new strain diversity in some widespread bacteria used to ripen cheeses. In sourdough starters, we discovered that acetic acid bacteria play previously underappreciated roles in the composition of starter communities and in functional attributes of these communities. In kombucha, our microbiome analyses revealed a widespread core microbiome of one acetic acid bacterium and one yeast that appear to be common and functionally significant in these systems. 

We also leveraged the appeal of these systems to teach diverse audiences about the ecology and evolution of microbiomes. In an undergraduate microbiology course at Tufts University, students adopted a unique fermented food microbiome, and used strains isolated from the microbiome to learn techniques in microbiology including culturing, microscopy, and genome sequencing. Students reported having an increased sense of ownership due to the open-ended and individualized nature of this teaching approach. At events at local museums and festivals around Massachusetts, we illustrated principles of microbiome diversity at a booth populated with fermented food activities. We also wrote articles about the ecology and evolution of microbes in fermented foods on our outreach website MicrobialFoods.org that are read by tens of thousands of visitors each month.

Modified by: Benjamin Wolfe
